Thanks to Dmitry Borodaenko for the suggestion. Closes 25349. Version 0.3.12 (tzdata v2008i) 12 Nov 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2008i ( ). Version 0.3.11 (tzdata v2008g) 7 Oct 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2008g ( ). Support Ruby 1.9.0 5. has now been removed in Ruby 1.9. Only use if it is available (it is preferable in Ruby 1.8 for performance reasons). Thanks to Jeremy Kemper and Pratik Naik for reporting this. Closes 22312. Apply a patch from Pratik Naik to replace assert calls that have been deprecated in the Ruby svn trunk. Closes 22308. Version 0.3.10 (tzdata v2008f) 16 Sep 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2008f ( ). Version 0.3.9 (tzdata v2008c) 27 May 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2008c ( ). Support loading timezone data in the latest trunk versions of Ruby 1.9. is now private, so call it using instead. Thanks to Jeremy Kemper and Pratik Naik for spotting this. Closes 19184. Prevent warnings from being output when running Ruby with the v or w command line options. Thanks to Paul McMahon for the patch. Closes 19719. Version 0.3.8 (tzdata v2008b) 24 Mar 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2008b ( ). Support loading timezone data in Ruby 1.9.0. Use if it is available instead of when constructing transition times. was added in Ruby 1.8.6. was removed in Ruby 1.9.0. Thanks to Joshua Peek for reporting this. Closes 17606. Modify some of the equality test cases to cope with the differences between Ruby 1.8.6 and Ruby 1.9.0. Version 0.3.7 (tzdata v2008a) 10 Mar 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2008a ( ). Version 0.3.6 (tzdata v2007k) 1 Jan 2008 Updated to tzdata version 2007k ( ). Removed deprecated RubyGems autorequire option. Version 0.3.5 (tzdata v2007h) 1 Oct 2007 Updated to tzdata version 2007h ( ). Version 0.3.4 (tzdata v2007g) 21 Aug 2007 Updated to tzdata version 2007g ( ). Version 0.3.3 (tzdata v2006p) 27 Nov 2006 Updated to tzdata version 2006p ( ). Version 0.3.2 (tzdata v2006n) 11 Oct 2006 Updated to tzdata version 2006n ( ). Note that this release of tzdata removes the country Serbia and Montenegro (CS) and replaces it with separate Serbia (RS) and Montenegro (ME) entries. Version 0.3.1 (tzdata v2006j) 21 Aug 2006 Remove colon from case statements to avoid warning in Ruby 1.8.5. 5198. Use temporary variable to avoid dynamic string warning from rdoc. Updated to tzdata version 2006j ( ). Version 0.3.0 (tzdata v2006g) 17 Jul 2006 New timezone data format. Timezone data now occupies less space on disk and takes less memory once loaded. 4142, 4144. Timezone data is defined in modules rather than classes. instances returned by are no longer instances of data classes, but are instead instances of new and classes. instances can now be used with and . 4240. Added a method that returns a object for a given identifier. Country index data is now defined in a single module that is independent of the class implementation. instances can now be used with and . 4240. has a new method that returns objects containing additional information (latitude, longitude and a description) relating to each . 4140. Time zones within a are now returned in an order that makes geographic sense. The zdumptest utility now checks local to utc conversions in addition to utc to local conversions. method defined on and that is equivalent to . The method of no longer raises an exception when passed an object with no identifier method. The method of no longer raises an exception when passed an object with no code method. method defined on that returns the hash of the code. method defined on that returns the hash of the identifier. Miscellaneous API documentation corrections and improvements. Timezone definition and indexes are now excluded from rdoc (the contents were previously ignored with anyway). Removed no longer needed directives from timezone data files (which are now excluded from the rdoc build). Installation of the gem now causes rdoc API documentation to be generated. 4905. When optimizing transitions to generate zone definitions, check the UTC and standard offsets separately rather than just the total offset to UTC. Fixes an incorrect abbreviation issue with Europe/London, Europe/Dublin and Pacific/Auckland. Eliminated unnecessary calls to give a minor performance gain. and now return all the instances/identifiers rather than just those associated with countries. 4146. Added , , and class methods to . Added a method to that converts a time in UTC to local time and then returns it formatted. is replaced with the timezone abbreviation for the given time (for example, EST or EDT). 4143. Fix escaping of quotes in . This affected country names and descriptions of time zones within countries. Version 0.2.2 (tzdata v2006g) 17 May 2006 Use class scoped instance variables to store the Timezone identifier and singleton instance. Loading a linked zone no longer causes the parent zone's identifier to be changed. The instance method of a linked zone class also now returns an instance of the linked zone class rather than the parent class. 4502. The zdumptest utility now compares the TZInfo zone identifier with the zdump zone identifier. The zdumptestall utility now exits if not supplied with enough parameters. Updated to tzdata version 2006g ( ). Version 0.2.1 (tzdata v2006d) 17 Apr 2006 Fix a performance issue caused in 0.2.0 with . Conversions performed on instances passed to are now cached as originally intended. Thanks to Michael Smedberg for spotting this. Fix a performance issue with the period search algorithm originally implemented in 0.1.0. The condition that was supposed to cause the search to terminate when enough periods had been found was only being evaluated in a small subset of cases. Thanks to Michael Smedberg and Jamis Buck for reporting this. Added abbreviation as an alias for . Updated to tzdata version 2006d ( ). Ignore any offset in instances passed in (as is already done for instances). All of the following now refer to the same UTC time (15:40 on 17 April 2006). Previously, the in the second line would have been interpreted as 20:40. Version 0.2.0 (tzdata v2006c) 3 Apr 2006 Use timestamps rather than objects in zone files for times between 1970 and 2037 (the range of ). Don't convert passed in objects to in most cases (provides a substantial performance improvement). Allow integer timestamps (time in seconds since 1970 1 1) to be used as well as and objects in all public methods that take times as parameters. Tool to compare TZInfo conversions with output from zdump. zone generation algorithm rewritten. Now based on the zic code. TZInfo is now 100% compatible with zic/zdump output. Riyadh Solar Time zones now included again (generation time has been reduced with changes). Use binary mode when writing zone and country files to get Unix (\n) new lines. Omit unnecessary quotes in zone identifier symbols. Omit the final transition to DST if there is a prior transition in the last year processed to standard time. Updated to tzdata version 2006c ( ). Version 0.1.2 (tzdata v2006a) 5 Feb 2006 Add lib directory to the load path when tzinfo is required. Makes it easier to use tzinfo gem when unpacked to vendor directory in rails. Updated to tzdata version 2006a ( ). rake task now handles running svn add and svn delete as new time zones and countries are added and old ones are removed. Return a better error when attempting to use a instance that was constructed with . This will occur when using Rails' . When the timezone identifier in the database is null, attempting to use the will now result in an exception rather than a . Version 0.1.1 (tzdata v2005q) 18 Dec 2005 Time zones that are defined by a single unbounded period (e.g. UTC) now work again. Updated to tzdata version 2005q. Version 0.1.0 (tzdata v2005n) 27 Nov 2005 and now allow resolution of ambiguous times (e.g. when switching from daylight savings to standard time). The behaviour of these methods when faced with an ambiguous local time has now changed. If you are using these methods you should check the documentation. Thanks to Cliff Matthews for suggesting this change. Added to (date isn't loaded by default in all environments). Use rake to build packages and documentation. License file is now included in gem distribution. Dates in definitions stored as Astronomical Julian Day numbers rather than as civil dates (improves performance creating instances). Added options to to allow generation of specific zones and countries. Moved class to . New class to store instances for a timezone and perform searches for periods. Time zones are now defined using blocks. instances are only created when they are needed. Thanks to Jamis Buck for the suggestion. Add options to to allow exclusion of specific zones and countries. Exclude the Riyadh Solar Time zones. The rules are only for 1987 to 1989 and take a long time to generate and process. Riyadh Solar Time is no longer observed. The last for each is now written out with an unbounded rather than arbitrary end time. Construct the offset in once when the is constructed rather than each time it is needed. and now keep a cache of loaded instances to avoid running which can be slow on some platforms. Updated to tzdata version 2005n. Version 0.0.4 (tzdata v2005m) 18 Sep 2005 Removed debug output accidentally included in the previous release. Fixed a bug in the generation of friendly zone identifiers (was inserting apostrophes into UTC, GMT, etc). Fixed operator (was comparing non existent attribute) Fixed error when period not found. Added test cases for , , , and some selected time zones. Version 0.0.3 (tzdata v2005m) 17 Sep 2005 Reduced visibility of some methods added in and . Added method to (returns the identifier). Added method to . Returns a more friendly version of the identifier. Added method to . Returns the friendly identifier. Added and operators to (compares identifiers). now includes . Added method to . Added and operators to (compares ISO 3166 country codes). now includes . New class that behaves the same as a but doesn't actually load in its definition until it is actually required. Modified and methods that return instances to return instances instead. This makes these methods much quicker. In Ruby on Rails, you can now show a drop down list of all time zones using the Rails helper method: Version 0.0.2 (tzdata v2005m) 13 Sep 2005 and data is now loaded into class rather than instance variables. This makes links more efficient and saves memory if creating specific and classes directly. is now defined as a symbol to save memory (was previously a string). s that were previously are now . and instances can now be returned using and . When passed an identifier, the method calls to return an instance of the specified timezone or country. Added new class methods to to return sets of zones and identifiers. Thanks to Scott Barron of Lunchbox Software for the suggestions in his article about using TZInfo with Rails ( ) Version 0.0.1 (tzdata v2005m) 29 Aug 2005 First release.

docs.title: TZInfo - Ruby Time Zone Library
docs.content: TZInfo Ruby Time Zone Library TZInfo is a Ruby library that provides access to time zone data and allows times to be converted using time zone rules. Data Sources TZInfo requires a source of time zone data. There are two options: 1. A zoneinfo directory containing timezone definition files. These files are generated from the IANA Time Zone Database using the utility. Most Unix like systems include a zoneinfo directory. 2. The TZInfo::Data library (the tzinfo data gem). TZInfo::Data contains a set of Ruby modules that are also generated from the IANA Time Zone Database. By default, TZInfo will attempt to use TZInfo::Data. If TZInfo::Data is not available (i.e. if fails), then TZInfo will search for a zoneinfo directory instead (using the search path specified by ). If no data source can be found, a exception will be raised when TZInfo is used. Further information is available in the wiki to help resolve errors. The default data source selection can be overridden by calling . Custom data sources can also be used. See the documentation for further details. Installation The TZInfo gem can be installed by running or by adding to your and running . To use the Ruby modules as the data source, TZInfo::Data will also need to be installed by running or by adding to your . IANA Time Zone Database The data returned and used by TZInfo is sourced from the IANA Time Zone Database. The Theory and pragmatics of the tz code and data document gives details of how the data is organized and managed. Example Usage To use TZInfo, it must first be required with: The class provides access to time zone data and methods for converting times. The method returns a list of valid time zone identifiers: A instance representing an individual time zone can be obtained with : A time can be converted to the local time of the time zone with : Local times with the appropriate offset for the time zone can be constructed with : Local times can be converted to UTC by using and calling on the result: The method can also be used to convert a time object to UTC. The offset of the time is ignored it is treated as if it were a local time for the time zone: Information about the time zone can be obtained from returned local times: Time zone information can be included when formatting times with using the and directives: The method can be used to obtain information about the observed time zone information at a particular time as a object: A list of transitions between periods where different rules are observed can be obtained with the method. The result is returned as an of objects: A list of the unique offsets used by a time zone can be obtained with the method. The result is returned as an of objects: All methods that accept a time as a parameter can be used with either instances of , or . Arbitrary like objects that respond to both and and optionally will be treated as if they are instances of . methods that both accept and return times will return an object with a type matching that of the parameter (actually a , or subclass when returning a local time): In addition to , which returns instances, the and methods can be used to construct local and instances with the appropriate offset: The , , and methods may raise a or a exception. signals that there is no equivalent UTC time (for example, during the transition from standard time to daylight savings time when the clocks are moved forward and an hour is skipped). signals that there is more than one equivalent UTC time (for example, during the transition from daylight savings time to standard time where the clocks are moved back and an hour is repeated): exceptions can only be resolved by adjusting the time, for example, by advancing an hour: exceptions can be resolved by setting the parameter and/or specifying a block to choose one of the interpretations: The default value of the parameter can also be set globally: TZInfo also provides information about ISO 3166 1 countries and their associated time zones via the class. A list of valid ISO 3166 1 (alpha 2) country codes can be obtained by calling : A instance representing an individual time zone can be obtained with : The method returns a list of the time zone identifiers used in a country: The method returns further information about the time zones used in a country as an of instances: The method returns an of instances for a country. A instance can be obtained from a using the method: For further detail, please refer to the API documentation for the and classes. Time Zone Selection The Time Zone Database maintainers recommend that time zone identifiers are not made visible to end users (see Names of timezones). Instead of displaying a list of time zone identifiers, time zones can be selected by the user's country. Call to obtain a list of objects, each with a unique and a that can be used for display purposes. Most countries have a single time zone. When choosing such a country, the time zone can be inferred and selected automatically. Some countries have multiple time zones. The method can be used to obtain a list of user friendly descriptions of the available options: Please note that country information available through TZInfo is intended as an aid to help users select a time zone data appropriate for their practical needs. It is not intended to take or endorse any position on legal or territorial claims. Compatibility TZInfo v2.0.0 requires a minimum of Ruby MRI 1.9.3 or JRuby 1.7 (in 1.9 mode or later). Thread Safety The and classes are thread safe. It is safe to use class and instance methods of and in concurrently executing threads. Instances of both classes can be shared across thread boundaries. Documentation API documentation for TZInfo is available on RubyDoc.info. License TZInfo is released under the MIT license, see LICENSE for details. Source Code Source code for TZInfo is available on GitHub. Issue Tracker Please post any bugs, issues, feature requests or questions about TZInfo to the GitHub issue tracker. Issues with the underlying time zone data should be raised on the Time Zone Database Discussion mailing list.

docs.title: README
docs.content: Unicode::DisplayWidth [![[version]](https://badge.fury.io/rb/unicode display width.svg)](https://badge.fury.io/rb/unicode display width) Determines the monospace display width of a string in Ruby. Implementation based on EastAsianWidth.txt and other data, 100% in Ruby. Other than wcwidth(), which fulfills a similar purpose, it does not rely on the OS vendor to provide an up to date method for measuring string width. Unicode version: 14.0.0 (September 2021) Supported Rubies: 2.7 , 2.6 , 2.5 , 2.4 Old Rubies that might still work: 2.3 , 2.2 , 2.1 , 2.0 , 1.9 Introduction to Character Widths Guessing the correct space a character will consume on terminals is not easy. There is no single standard. Most implementations combine data from East Asian Width, some General Categories, and hand picked adjustments. How this Library Handles Widths Further at the top means higher precedence. Please expect changes to this algorithm with every MINOR version update (the X in 1.X.0)! Width | Characters | Comment | | X | (user defined) | Overwrites any other values 1 | | Backspace (total width never below 0) 0 | , , , , , , , , | C0 control codes that do not change horizontal width 1 | | SOFT HYPHEN 2 | | TWO EM DASH 3 | | THREE EM DASH 0 | General Categories: Mn, Me, Cf (non arabic) | Excludes ARABIC format characters 0 | | HANGUL JUNGSEONG 0 | , , | Ignorable ranges 2 | East Asian Width: F, W | Full width characters 2 | , , , , | Full width ranges 1 or 2 | East Asian Width: A | Ambiguous characters, user defined, default: 1 1 | All other codepoints | Install Install the gem with: $ gem install unicode display width Or add to your Gemfile: gem 'unicode display width' Usage Ambiguous Characters The second parameter defines the value returned by characters defined as ambiguous: Custom Overwrites You can overwrite how to handle specific code points by passing a hash (or even a proc) as third parameter: Emoji Support Experimental emoji support is included. It will adjust the string's size for modifier and zero width joiner sequences. You will need to add the unicode emoji gem to your Gemfile: You can then activate the emoji string width adjustments by passing as fourth parameter: Usage with String Extension Activated by default. Will be deactivated in version 2.0: You can actively opt out from the string extension with: Usage From the CLI Use this one liner to print out display widths for strings from the command line: Replace "一" with the actual string to measure Other Implementations & Discussion Python: https://github.com/jquast/wcwidth JavaScript: https://github.com/mycoboco/wcwidth.js C: https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/ mgk25/ucs/wcwidth.c C for Julia: https://github.com/JuliaLang/utf8proc/issues/2 See unicode x for more Unicode related micro libraries. docs.title: URI
docs.content: URI URI is a module providing classes to handle Uniform Resource Identifiers RFC3986. Features Uniform way of handling URIs. Flexibility to introduce custom URI schemes. Flexibility to have an alternate URI::Parser (or just different patterns and regexp's). Installation Add this line to your application's Gemfile: And then execute: $ bundle Or install it yourself as: $ gem install uri Usage Development After checking out the repo, run to install dependencies. Then, run to run the tests. You can also run for an interactive prompt that will allow you to experiment. To install this gem onto your local machine, run . To release a new version, update the version number in , and then run , which will create a git tag for the version, push git commits and tags, and push the file to rubygems.org. Contributing Bug reports and pull requests are welcome on GitHub at https://github.com/ruby/uri.

docs.title: Webrick
docs.content: Webrick WEBrick is an HTTP server toolkit that can be configured as an HTTPS server, a proxy server, and a virtual host server. WEBrick features complete logging of both server operations and HTTP access. WEBrick supports both basic and digest authentication in addition to algorithms not in RFC 2617. A WEBrick server can be composed of multiple WEBrick servers or servlets to provide differing behavior on a per host or per path basis. WEBrick includes servlets for handling CGI scripts, ERB pages, Ruby blocks and directory listings. WEBrick also includes tools for daemonizing a process and starting a process at a higher privilege level and dropping permissions. WEBrick is suitable for use in testing and for development. However, while the developers of WEBrick will attempt to fix security issues, they do not encourage the use of WEBrick to serve production web applications that may be subject to hostile input. Installation Add this line to your application's Gemfile: And then execute: $ bundle Or install it yourself as: $ gem install webrick Usage To create a new WEBrick::HTTPServer that will listen to connections on port 8000 and serve documents from the current user's public html folder: To run the server you will need to provide a suitable shutdown hook as starting the server blocks the current thread: Development After checking out the repo, run to install dependencies. Then, run to run the tests. You can also run for an interactive prompt that will allow you to experiment. To install this gem onto your local machine, run . To release a new version, update the version number in , and then run , which will create a git tag for the version, push git commits and tags, and push the file to rubygems.org. Contributing Bug reports and pull requests are welcome on GitHub at https://github.com/ruby/webrick. License The gem is available as open source under the terms of the 2 Clause BSD License.
